Ä€nanda addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Although the TathÄgata has explained the second principle, now observing the person in the world who unties knots, if he does not know the origin of the knots, I believe this person will never be able to untie them.
Previously he doubted the sameness and difference of cause and effect, now he doubts the unravelling and binding of the faculties and objects, thus he says the second principle.

However, although the reason for the arising of the faculties was extensively shown before, he did not specifically point out where the binding is, and the meaning of the unravelling of the binding has not yet been clarified. He wishes to point it out, so that it can be clearly recognized, thus he uses the analogy given by the Buddha in the previous text to illustrate his own confusion.
World-Honored One!

I and the learners in the assembly are also like this. From beginningless time, we have been simultaneously extinguished and simultaneously born with all ignorance. Although we have attained such wholesome roots of much learning and are called renunciants, we are still like a malaria patient with a two-day fever.
The all ignorance refers to the ignorance of the entire realm. It comprehensively includes all the views and thoughts of the two obstacles, and is therefore called all.

Beginning with the confusion of truth, it follows sentient beings, being born and extinguished without separation. Therefore, the above text says, Falsely born through combination, falsely dying through combination. Therefore, it is said to be simultaneously extinguished and simultaneously born.

Although the learners of the first fruit have not yet eliminated the thoughts, they are already called the destruction of the obstacle of afflictions and have attained the realization of emptiness of persons, but they have not yet completely eliminated the obstacle of the knowable, and the attachment to dharmas still remains. Therefore, it is said to be like a malaria patient with a two-day fever.
Second, requesting instruction on the binding and unbinding.
I only wish that with great compassion, you will take pity on those who are drowning. Today, what is the binding of body and mind?
From what is it called unbinding?
It will also enable sentient beings suffering in the future to escape from cyclic existence and not fall into the three realms.
Having said this, he and the great assembly prostrated with their five limbs to the ground, rained tears, and earnestly awaited the unsurpassed revelation of the Buddha, the Thus-Come One.
They were unable to transcend birth and death since beginningless time, all due to bondage.
Now, awaiting its unbinding, without obstruction and without attachment, without sincere entreaty, there is no way to gain understanding, thus they rained tears seeking instruction.
Second, the extensive revelation by the Thus-Come One, in five parts:
First, the World-Honored One touches the crown of the head.

At that time, the World-Honored One, out of compassion for Ä€nanda and all those in the assembly who were still learning, and also for the sake of all sentient beings in the future, to provide the cause for transcending the world and to serve as the eyes for the future, used his hand, which emitted the purple-gold light of the JambÅ« River, to touch the crown of Ä€nanda's head.

The crown of the head is the general of all the faculties, and the hand is the essential for unbinding. Touching and stirring it, there will be a time of unbinding; patting and comforting, causing them to know the profound meaning.
Second, the buddhas emit light.

At that moment, the worlds of the buddhas in the ten directions shook in six ways. The tathÄgatas dwelling in the worlds each had a jeweled light emerge from their crowns. The lights simultaneously came from those worlds to Jetavana, pouring down on the tathÄgata's crown. The great assembly attained what they had never had before.
The ground of nescience is the six sense faculties. Shaking and unsettling, this leads to unravelling the knots.
The buddhas emit light and pour it on the crown of one buddha, expressing the unobstructedness of one and many, and the equality of self and other.
The following text is indicated by the buddhas, and this buddha explains it. They speak the same and realize the same, with no other path.
Question:
This sÅ«tra has had light emitted four times up to this point. Only in this passage do the buddhas emit light together, and they also speak the same. What is so special about this?
Answer:

The first is to explain the teaching and break with wrong views. The second is to distinguish delusion and reveal truth. The third is to determine views and give rise to wisdom. The present is to enter contemplation and perfect practice.
The first three [parts] rely on the teachings to give rise to understanding, but are not yet able to eliminate hindrances;

In this text, the contemplation is perfected and breaks through delusions, directly agitating the fundamental ignorance and entering the principle of the Dharma realm. Therefore, the buddhas emit light, demonstrating together that the essence of unravelling the knots is not two sources.

Therefore, know that expounding the teachings, breaking through delusions, revealing the true, distinguishing the false, establishing faith, and perfecting understanding, are all for today's practice and attainment of realization. It is not a trivial matter, so it is different from the previous text.
Third, the same explanation of the root of the knots.
Then, Ä€nanda and the great assembly all heard the tathÄgatas in the ten directions with different mouths speaking the same words, addressing Ä€nanda, saying:
Excellent, Ä€nanda!
If you wish to know the innate ignorance that causes you to revolve in birth and death, the root of the knots, it is none other than your six sense faculties.
If you wish to know the unsurpassed bodhi that will enable you to quickly realize blissful liberation and the wondrous permanence of tranquility, it is also none other than your six sense faculties.

When the enlightened mind first arises, the deluded subject and object are born. Once the tranquil nature is divided, the six sense faculties become distinct. When the sense faculties and objects pair up, the nature of karma arises, and one revolves without end, long bound to birth and death. These six sense faculties are the source of the bondage of birth and death.

If there is no thought in a single moment, the deluded subject and object completely vanish. The sense faculties, objects, and consciousnesses are instantly eliminated. There is no true nature to attain and no delusion to remove. The enlightened nature is perfectly clear, and the Dharma eye is pure. These six sense faculties are the source of self-mastery, liberation, bliss, and the wondrous permanence.

It is just like ice and water, which change due to the movement of qi. Although their appearances differ, their wet nature is always the same. The same is true for the continuity of bondage and liberation.
Fourth, Ä€nanda requests again.
Although Ä€nanda has heard such Dharma sounds, his mind is still unclear. He bows his head and says to the Buddha:
How can you say that my birth and death, samsara, bliss, and the wondrous permanence are all the same as the six sense faculties, and not something else?

The fundamental of defilement and purity is only these six faculties, there is no other dharma. If one gives rise to views in regard to them, one wanders in the cycle of birth and death; if one forgets attachment in regard to them, one attains the constant bliss of nirvana.
Without breaking through the grasping of dharmas, who can thoroughly understand this?
Therefore, [the Buddha] is again asked to give instruction, hoping for revelation.
Fifth, the Buddha's explanation, in two parts:
First, the prose section, in two parts:
First, a double indication.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
The faculties and sense objects have the same source, bondage and liberation are non-dual, the nature of consciousness is false, like a flower in the sky.
The three of faculties, objects, and consciousness have no separate essence, they are only the one true enlightenment, therefore it is said they have the same source.

If one clings to views and does not let go, falsely giving rise to grasping and attachment, forcefully dividing into pure and defiled, horizontally calculating body and mind, from beginning to end, thought after thought, arising and ceasing, therefore it is said to be bondage.

Understanding that appearances are devoid of characteristics, discrimination does not arise. Subject and object are tranquil, and thoughts and memories are completely exhausted. Not grasping at a single dharma, the essence of the one true reality manifests. The mind is equal to space, without distinction. Therefore, it is called liberation.

As for the nature of consciousness being false and illusory, like empty flowers, it is a mutual reflection of the faculties and objects. Above it says the faculties and objects reflect this nature of consciousness, and now it says the nature of consciousness reflects the faculties and objects. Therefore, the three have the same source and are also the same in being false and illusory. Therefore, the previous text says, The seer, the seen, and the conceptualized characteristics are like flowers in the sky.
This is the false and illusory nature of consciousness.
It also says, This seeing and its objects are originally the wondrous, pure, and bright essence of bodhi.
This is the same source of the faculties and objects.
Second, the double explanation, in two parts:
First, generally revealing the lack of nature.
Ä€nanda!
The knowledge that arises due to objects and the characteristics that exist due to the faculties are without any nature of their own, like two reeds supporting each other.

The six sense organs are formed by grasping at sense objects, and in response to the sense organs, there are sense objects. Once the sense organs and sense objects are established, deluded consciousness arises.

The deluded consciousness is able to transform the two dharmas of sense organs and sense objects. Therefore, the sense organs, sense objects, and consciousness mutually rely on each other. Each is empty in essence, yet each is established. Therefore, they are like two bundles of reeds supporting each other.
Second, specifically clarifying bondage and liberation.
Therefore, you should now know that if knowing and seeing establish knowing, it is the basis of ignorance;
If knowing and seeing are without seeing, this is nirvana, the pure true nature without outflows. How can there be any other thing within this?
Because Ananda asked again:
How can you say that the cycle of birth and death and the wonderful permanence of bliss are all the six sense organs, and nothing else?

Therefore, the Buddha first showed that the three of sense organs, sense objects, and consciousness are only one false illusion, with the same source of nature. Delusion, bondage, and liberation are truly not different paths. Based on this, he specifically showed the conclusion to eliminate doubts, and based on understanding, he formed the contemplation, and the wonderful fruit can be hoped for.
As for knowing is, it briefly mentions two of the six sense organs.
Establishing cognition also omits the character seeing, which is reflected in the following text.

It means that if one does not understand the naturelessness of the six sense faculties and three matters, and establishes them as real existences, giving rise to conceptual attachments, afflictions and karma will arise, one will take on the cycle of rebirth, and willlessly enter various destinies. This is where the six sense faculties are the root of the bonds of ignorance and birth and death.

If one can understand the true nature and realize the falsity of this, and not give rise to grasping and attachment, then false knowledge, views, and awareness will vanish and become empty and tranquil. There is only the perfect and pure precious awareness. This is where the six sense faculties are the originally pure and clean essence of bodhi and nirvana. What other thing could be said to be a different cause?
Therefore, the Prajnaparamita Sutra says, If one sees all characteristics as non-characteristics, then one sees the Tathagata.
Above it says, This seeing and its conditions are originally the wondrous, pure, and bright essence of bodhi.
This is precisely the refutation of ignorance and the grasping of dharmas, and the accomplishment of the perfect and unobstructed contemplation method.

Second, the main verse, in six parts:
First, two verses on setting forth the main point and refuting attachments, in two parts:

First, using logical reasoning to directly refute, The true nature of conditioned phenomena is empty, because they arise from conditions, like an illusion. Unconditioned phenomena have no arising or ceasing, and are unreal, like a flower in the sky.
This text directly refutes the ignorance of the dharma-nature, and those who cling to the existence or non-existence of real substance are all deluded about the true nature.
The one true dharma realm is originally not dualistic, therefore this refutes both, which is the cause for unravelling the knots.

Here, the four statements, the first two refute the conditioned, and the last two refute the unconditioned. Only when these two are not established can the meaning of the one characteristic of the dharma realm be revealed.

As for the statement the true nature of the conditioned is empty, the word true nature is precisely the main point of the argument, distinguishing the dharma, and extends to the second inference below, referring to the one true middle way of ultimate truth. The inference should be stated as follows:
The true nature of the conditioned is originally empty and non-existent, because it arises from conditions, just like an illusion;
The true nature of the unconditioned is originally unreal, because it has no arising or ceasing, just like a flower in the sky.

Because of these two inferences, the three parts are not lacking, the main point is clearly distinguished, and there are no faults. In the Treatise on the Precious Hand, this is taken as a good establishment.
In the second inference, the reason comes first and the thesis comes later. The translator's wording is convenient, and there is no loss.

The meaning revealed here is the one true equality, free from all opposites. Therefore, the Zhong lun says, If a dharma is established through dependence, this dharma still depends on being established. Now there is no dependence and no dharma to be established.
This shows that in the ultimate truth, all characteristics are left behind, speech is cut off, and the mind is extinguished. The grasping of dharmas due to ignorance is exhausted here.
Second, revealing the faults and using them to refute.
Delusion is spoken of to reveal the true, but delusion and truth are both delusions. Even non-true and non-false are not true. How can the seen and the seer be seen?

One should know that all dharmas are inexpressible and inconceivable, and are therefore called 'suchness.'
One should know that if there is a true nature that can be attained, it is all false, and therefore it is said that the false and the true are both false.
The two phrases below still not further refute the attachment to falsity. The first phrase continues the previous refutation, saying that there is still no true or not true, and not true is false.
The next phrase is the actual refutation, saying, How can there still be the seer and the seen? The faculties and consciousnesses are both called seeing, and the seen is the object.

This completely refutes the two minds of true and false, and all opposed and dependent dharmas are all nonexistent, and is then called the manifestation of the pure dharma realm, the one true equality.
The two verses above are precisely the praise of the previous statement that the faculties and objects have the same source.
The original nature is still not true or false, how could it be possible to have faculties, objects, and consciousness?
Therefore, the faculties, objects, and consciousnesses have this same source.
Second, two verses conclude that bondage and liberation have the same essence.
In the middle, there is no real nature, therefore it is like intertwined reeds.
This praises the previous statement that the faculties and objects give rise to each other, and the seeing and seen have no nature, like intertwined reeds.

The sages of the three vehicles cut off afflictions and realize the truth, and do not follow the bonds of karma, therefore they are called liberated.
This is all due to the faculties being deluded or enlightened, and there is no other fork in the road, therefore there are no two paths.
You observe the nature in the middle, emptiness and existence are both not.
Since there is no nature in the middle of the intersection, what existence is there to be refuted, and what non-existence is there to be retained? Because there is no duality in the one nature.
Master Sengzhao said:
Since existence is not existent, then non-existence is also non-existent.
This directly reveals the middle way of the faculties and objects, and is also the meaning of the faculties and objects having the same source above.
Delusion and obscurity are ignorance, and the arising of illumination is liberation.
This praises the text of knowing and seeing establishing knowing, etc. above.
